“James,” he says, “I’d like you to help me with a bitchfriend.”

“Ok, so who’s your bitchfriend?”

“Just thought of it as a way of getting around. The red one would be good for camping and transporting you and all your mates, once we turn them into dog-headed people. You’re even getting licenses.”

“Hello, Dianne,” Bruce says, “are the kids in?”

“Yes, they are,” Dianne says, “Obviously they would if it was a weekend. I was preparing to go for a walk round the block with them just now.”

“That’s ok,” you say. “We won’t delay you too long. How’s Kate?”

“She’s quite sleepy right now. She had running around the garden after breakfast today and is completely winded. I guess it will be sometime before she wakes up.”

“Yeah, we just wanted to check up on her.”

“That’s fine,” Dianne says. She then calls for her children and they come down eagerly. They each look like they could be middle-school-going.

“Mom, are those the dogs from next door?” you hear Amanda ask. Based on her voice, she does not seem to know what has happened to you, which appears to confirm your suspicions that reality has changed.

“Yes, they are, they’re just looking after Kate while we’re gone.”

“I understand, Mom.” This is Jack’s voice.

“What’s going on?” Kate asks, her vocal cords working for the first time. “Where’s my body? Where’s my tail? Why have I got hands? Why are there dog-headed people looking at me?”

“And his brother,” the second new female (‘Jessica’) says.
“Ya, sons of the top dog-head on the police force,” the first new male says.
“And we’re the neighbors, to them,” the second new male says.

You are amazed that they know about you so well.

“Wait a minute, who are you dogs?” Kate asks in confusion.

“Ok, we need names,” one of the males says.

You turn to the new females first. “You’re Sarah and you’re Jessica.” They like the names.

“Sarah? As in your sister?”

“Yes.”

“Ok. Actually, now that I think of it, Chihuahuas are her favorite breed of dog. She was quite drawn to me when she first saw me. If you don’t mind I’d like to meet her up close.”

Meanwhile, Bruce has named the males Charlie and Matt. The two become adjusted to their role in the new reality as friends of Bruce, and supportive of their sister’s relationship with him. You then come up with an idea.

“When I entrusted you with that pencil,” you whisper in Bruce’s ears when the Chihuahuas are not looking, “you went and turned my mom and she came back without any clue what happened to her. Maybe if we turn the Morrisons while they’re not here, we can make look like they and the Chihuahuas were always related and they’d be none the wiser.”
